questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause drug-induced lupus syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Procainamide Procainamide class IA drug which causes drug-induced lupus syndrome Procainamide-induced lupus syndrome

Highyeild:

In individuals who are “slow acetylators,” the procainamide-induced lupus syndrome develops more often and earlier during treatment than among rapid acetylators. it is more common in slow acetylators than in rapid acetylators. Drugs causing side effects: INH Hydralazine Minocycline Methyldopa Chlorpromazine Quinidine Procainamide

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. LIGNOCAINE The main toxicity is dose-related neurological effects: Drowsiness, nausea, paresthesias, blurred vision, disorientation, nystagmus, twitchings, and fits. Lidocaine has practically no proarrhythmic potential and is the least cardiotoxic antiarrhythmic. Only excessive doses cause cardiac depression and hypotension. Option: C. ESMOLOL IS NOT ASSOCIATED WITH DRUG-INDUCED LUPUS SYNDROME. Option: D. FLECAINIDE IS NOT ASSOCIATED WITH DRUG-INDUCED LUPUS SYNDROME. It is reserved for resistant cases of paroxysmal AF and life-threatening sustained VT in patients not having associated CHF.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about cinchonism caused by Quinidine?

options.label: B
options.text: Cinchonism is related to plasma Quinidine concentration

options.label: C
options.text: Cinchonism can be managed by dose reduction

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Highyeild:

Quinidine: It also can produce cinchonism, a syndrome that includes headache and tinnitus Cinchonism usually is related to elevated plasma Quinidine concentrations and can be managed by dose reduction Cinchonism is a dose-dependent side effect of Quinidine

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It includes headache and tinnitus Option: B . Cinchonism is related to plasma Quinidine concentration Option: C. Cinchonism can be managed by dose reduction note: all are correct statements.

questions.text: About adenosine, all are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Administered as a rapid intravenous bolus for the acute termination of re-entrant supraventricular arrhythmias

options.label: B
options.text: Used to produce controlled hypotension during some surgical procedures

options.label: C
options.text: Short-acting due to rapid uptake and inactivation

options.label: D
options.text: Can be given by peripheral veins while giving a bolus

questions.correct_answer: D. Can be given by peripheral veins while giving a bolus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Can be given by peripheral veins while giving a bolus

Highyeild:

Adenosine: Naturally occurring nucleoside MOA: Adenosine activates acetylcholine-sensitive K+ current in the atrium and sinus, and AV nodes, resulting in Shortening of APD Hyperpolarization Slowing of normal automaticity USE: Administered as a rapid intravenous bolus for the acute termination of re-entrant supraventricular arrhythmias, PSVT Used to produce controlled hypotension during some surgical procedures and in the diagnosis of coronary artery disease It is short-acting due to the rapid uptake and inactivation of adenosine deaminase inside the cells T1/2 = 10 seconds Preferably given by large central veins while giving bolus because if we give in the peripheral vein, it will get deactivated until it reaches the heart.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Administered as a rapid intravenous bolus for the acute termination of re-entrant supraventricular arrhythmias Option: B . Used to produce controlled hypotension during some surgical procedures Option: C . Short-acting due to rapid uptake and inactivation note: a, b, and c are true statements.

questions.text: Following adverse effects are seen with adenosine except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dry Cough

Highyeild:

Adenosine Contraindications/Precautions Poison/drug induced tachycardia is contraindicated 2nd and 3rd degree block is contraindicated Transient side effects; flushing, CP, asystole, brady, ectopy Less effective with theophylline or caffeine If used for VT may cause worsening of clinical condition Transient periods of sinus brady or ventricular ectopy common after termination of SVT Safe in pregnancy Adverse effects of adenosine: Adverse effects are short-lived because the drug is transported into cells and deaminated so rapidly

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Transient asystole is common but usually lasts less than 5 Option B and D. Most patients feel a sense of chest fullness and dyspnea when administering therapeutic doses (6 to 12 mg) of adenosine . DRY COUGH IS CAUSED BY ACE INHIBITORS.

questions.text: The drug of choice in most of the cases of acute paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenosine

Highyeild:

In most cases, acute paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is Adenosine because this arrhythmia lasts for a few minutes. So, we want a drug that acts faster and has short-duration action. Adenosine is short-acting due to the rapid uptake and inactivation of adenosine by deaminase inside the cells. T1/2 = 10 seconds Preferably given by large central veins while giving bolus because if we give in a peripheral vein, it will get deactivated until it reaches the heart.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C. verapamil/diltiazem/esmolol Oral verapamil/diltiazem/propranolol/sotalol are also used in PSVT, BUT HERE QUESTION IS REGARDING DOC. Option: D. QUINIDINE is effective in many atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, it is seldom used now because of the risk of adverse effects, including that of torsades de pointes, sudden cardiac arrest, or VF

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Isosorbide Mononitrate?

options.label: A
options.text: An active metabolite of isosorbide dinitrate

options.label: B
options.text: Undergoes high first-pass metabolism when given orally

options.label: D
options.text: Longer acting formulation is used for prophylaxis of angina

questions.correct_answer: B. Undergoes high first-pass metabolism when given orally
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Undergoes high first-pass metabolism when given orally

Highyeild:

Isosorbide mononitrate: An active metabolite of isosorbide dinitrate When given orally, it undergoes little first-pass metabolism Bioavailability is high Not used sublingual Interindividual differences are minimal The longer-acting formulation is used for prophylaxis of angina NOTE: All Nitrates except isosorbide mononitrate undergo extensive and variable first-pass metabolism in the liver.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. An active metabolite of isosorbide dinitrate Option: C. Not used sublingual Option: D. The longer-acting formulation is used for prophylaxis of angina note: all are true statements.

questions.text: Longest acting nitrate among the following is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Penta erythritol tetra nitrate Penta erythritol tetra nitrate is the longest acting, and Amyl nitrite is the shortest acting among the nitrate group

Highyeild:

Erythrityl tetranitrate and pentaerythritol tetranitrate These are longer-acting nitrates used only for chronic prophylaxis. Sustained release oral preparations are now available for dosing 2–3 times daily. There has been considerable skepticism about the efficacy of long-acting nitrates orally administered. Studies with high doses have shown that first-pass metabolism in the liver can be saturated and haemodynamic effects lasting 4–6 hours do occur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C- short-acting nitrates

questions.text: Among the following options, the important action of nitrates in angina is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreases preload

Highyeild:

In stable angina, the primary mechanism of nitrates is to reduce the workload on the heart by reducing preload and, at higher concentrations, reducing after-load. The primary mechanism in Prinzmetal angina by nitrates is endothelium-independent coronary vasodilatation. The relaxant effect on larger coronary vessels is the principal action of nitrates benefiting variant angina by counteracting coronary spasm. In classical angina, the primary effect is to reduce cardiac work by action on peripheral vasculature, though increased blood supply to the ischaemic area may contribute. Exercise tolerance of angina patients is improved because the same amount of exercise causes lesser augmentation of cardiac work.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Coronary vasodilation Option: C. Decreases afterload Option: D. Decreases heart rate note: a,c, and d are the wrong statements.

questions.text: Which of the following Pharmacodynamic features are seen with nitrates?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Highyeild:

Classification Coronary vasodilators Nitrites & nitrates according to duration of action Shot acting (3 to 60 min) Amyl nitrite, nitroglycerin (sublingual), isosorbide dinitrate Intermediate acting(3 to 6hrs) Isosorbide dinitrate,nitroglycerin (ointment) Long acting(6 to 10 hrs) Erythirtyl tetranitrate, nitroglycerin (trans-cutaneous

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Tolerance: Tolerance develops on continuous usage of nitrates because of the generation of reactive oxygen species, which inhibits nitrate activating enzyme mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase Option: B. Cross tolerance: Seen among all nitrates Option: C. Dependence: Continuous usage leads to dependence, and Sudden withdrawal will result in spasms of coronary and peripheral blood vessels. MI and sudden deaths may occur

questions.text: The following are true about nitrate tolerance except:

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The reason for tolerance is the generation of reactive oxygen species

questions.correct_answer: B. Tolerance is seen with intermittent use of sublingual GTN for attacks of angina
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tolerance is seen with intermittent use of sublingual GTN for attacks of angina Tolerance Tolerance develops on continuous usage of nitrates because of the generation of reactive oxygen species, which inhibits nitrate activating enzyme mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase Tolerance to nitrates can be overcome by giving drug-free intervalsIntermittent use of sublingual GTN for attacks of angina will not produce tolerance Tolerance develops to GTN, when used orally, transdermally or by continuous i.v. Infusion round the clock and with long-acting agents (sustained release)Tolerance seen with higher dosesCross tolerance occurs among nitrates.

questions.text: A person complains of a headache only when he starts his work on Monday, and the headache decreases on subsequent days of work. On weekends he will be fine, and only on Monday, he once again gets a headache. From the history, the person may be working in the following industry:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Explosives

Highyeild:

“Monday disease” is seen among workers working in nitrate (the principal component of fertilizer and explosives) industries. When they are exposed to nitrates, they develop headaches after they come to work on Monday due to vasodilatation caused by nitrates. This is called Monday disease. After continuously working through the week, they develop tolerance to headaches, but the nitrate effect will be absent when they are on leave on Sunday. Once they come to work on Monday, they again develop headaches due to vasodilatation caused by nitrates.

questions.text: Verapamil acts through blocking:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

L-type calcium channel L-type calcium channel, Nimodipine is a dihydropyridine L-type calcium channel blocker. Calcium channel blockers prevent calcium from entering cells in the heart and blood vessel walls and are often used to treat high blood pressure. Nimodipine acts on the CACNA1C calcium influx gene.

Highyeild:

L-type calcium channel means long-lasting. Verapamil, Diltiazem, and dihydropyridines act by blocking L type calcium channels. The N-type of calcium channel is a neuronal calcium channel blocked by Gabapentin, and pregabalin. T type of calcium channel is a Transient calcium channel blocked by Flunarazine and Ethosuximide.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. N-type calcium channel- Many known N-type calcium channel blockers function to inhibit channel activity, although the most notable blockers are ω-conotoxins . Option: C. T-type calcium channel- The co-administration of T-type calcium channel blockers with standard Parkinson's disease medications is most prevalent in Japan, and several clinical studies have shown significant efficacy. However, most of these drugs are experimental and operate in a non-specific manner. Option: D. P/Q type calcium channel: only two specific P/Q-type blockers are known: both are peptides deriving from the spider venom of Agelenopsis aperta, ω-agatoxins . Other peptidic calcium channel blockers with activity at P/Q channels are available, albeit with less selectivity.

questions.text: CCB used for subarachnoid hemorrhage is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nimodipine Nimodipine is used in subarachnoid hemorrhage, and it crosses BBB and inhibits reflex vasospasm during a head injury.

Highyeild:

Nimodipine It is a short-acting DHP that penetrates the blood-brain barrier very efficiently due to high lipid solubility and has a high affinity for the cerebral blood vessels. It is believed to relax cerebral vasculature selectively and is approved for the prevention and treatment of neurological deficits due to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid haemorrhage or ruptured congenital intracranial aneurysms. Side effects are headache, flushing, dizziness, palpitation, and nausea.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Clevidipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker indicated for the reduction of blood pressure when oral therapy is not feasible or not desirable. Clevidipine is used IV only, and practitioners titrate this drug to lower blood pressure. It has a half-life of approximately one minute. Option: B. Felodipine is a medicine used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and to prevent angina (heart-related chest pain). It is a calcium channel blocker that helps lower blood pressure and reduces the heart's workload. This helps prevent heart attacks and strokes. Option: C. Isradipine is a calcium channel blocker of the dihydropyridine class. It is usually prescribed to treat high blood pressure to reduce the risk of stroke and heart attack.

questions.text: Ankle edema due to Amlodipine is due to:

options.label: B
options.text: Greater dilatation of precapillary Vessels than postcapillary vessels

options.label: C
options.text: Water and sodium reabsorption at tissue

questions.correct_answer: B. Greater dilatation of precapillary Vessels than postcapillary vessels
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Greater dilatation of precapillary Vessels than postcapillary vessels Greater dilatation of precapillary Vessels than postcapillary vessels Ankle edema due to Amlodipine is due to: Because of greater dilatation of precapillary than postcapillary vessels at the ankle.

Highyeild:

Amlodipine Pharmacokinetically it is the most distinct DHP and the most popular. Oral absorption is slow but complete; peak blood level occurs. After 6 to 9 hr—the early vasodilator side effects (palpitation, flushing, headache, postural dizziness) are largely avoided. Because of less extensive and less variable first-pass metabolism, its oral bioavailability is higher and more consistent. The volume of distribution and t½ is exceptionally long: diurnal fluctuation in blood level is small, and action extends over the following day.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A and C. Ankle edema is not due to fluid retention or inflammation.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pitting Pedal edema

Highyeild:

Non-pitting pedal edema is seen with calcium channel blocker due to greater dilatation of precapillary than postcapillary vessels. Bradycardia(with verapamil and diltiazem) Reflex tachycardia with dihydropyridines Headache, flushing Constipation Gingival hyperplasia Non-pitting Pedal edema Hypotension

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Headache, also known as cephalalgia, is the symptom of pain in the face, head, or neck. It can occur as a migraine, tension-type headache, or cluster headache. There is an increased risk of depression in those with severe headaches. Headaches can occur as a result of many conditions. Option: B. Constipation is a bowel dysfunction that makes bowel movements infrequent or hard to pass. The stool is often hard and dry. Other symptoms may include abdominal pain, bloating, and feeling as if one has not completely passed the bowel movement. Option: C. Gingival hyperplasia The most common is chronic inflammatory gingival enlargement, when the gingivae are soft and discolored. This is caused by tissue edema and infective cellular infiltration caused by prolonged exposure to bacterial plaque, and is treated with conventional periodontal treatment, such as scaling and root planing. Options A, B, C- Adverse effects of ccbs except pitting pedal edema.

questions.text: A patient was on an anti-anginal drug. He had difficulty driving his car at night due to disturbances in nocturnal vision with flashing lights. The drug known to cause this is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ivabradine

Highyeild:

Ivabradine Acts by selectively inhibiting the current in the SA node, known as the ‘funny current’ (If) Vision disturbance at night is seen due to the role of (If) in the retina. Apart from excess bradycardia, the most important adverse effect is a visual disturbance. Extrasystoles, prolongation of P-R interval, headache, dizziness, and nausea are the other problems. It should not be used if the heart rate is more than 60/min, in sick sinus, and in AF. Concurrent use of drugs which prolong Q-T or which inhibit CYP3A4 is contraindicated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Trimetazidine does not produce this side effect usually well tolerated- gastric burining, dizziness and muscle cramps. Option: C. Ranolazine - can cause postural hypotension, headache and dyspepsia. Option: D. Nicorandil causes palpitation, flushing, large painful aphthous ulcers in mouth which heal on stopping nicorandil have been reported.

questions.text: Which of the following acts by inhibiting late Na Channels in myocardium?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ranolazine Ranolazine is a medicine used for the management of angina (heart-related chest pain). It helps to prevent new attacks of angina, but it does not stop an acute attack, once it has started. It relieves chest pain by making the heart work more efficiently.

Highyeild:

Acts by inhibiting late Na Channels in the myocardium and inhibits fatty acid oxidation Through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, Reduction in Ca2+ overload in the myocardium during ischaemia decreases contractility and has a cardioprotective effect

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Trimetazidine inhibits fatty acid oxidation Option: C. Ivabradine inhibits funny Na channel Option: D. Fasudil inhibits Rhokinase

questions.text: Which antianginal drug exert cardioprotective action by stimulating ischemic preconditioning?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nicorandil

Highyeild:

Ischaemic preconditioning: Is a phenomenon in which brief periods of ischaemia and reperfusion exert a cardioprotective effect on subsequent total vascular occlusion, and involves opening of mitochondrial ATP sensitive K+ channels. Nicorandil is believed to exert cardioprotective action by simulating ‘ischaemic preconditioning’ as a result of activation of mitochondrial KATP channels.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, D . Are not known to produce cardioprotective action by stimulating the ischemic preconditioning effect.

questions.text: Among the following options, the coronary steal phenomenon is seen with:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dipyridamole a. Dipyridamole dilates subendocardial coronaries in Non-ischemic areas (Coronary steal phenomenon). b. This causes a redistribution of blood to non-ischemic areas, Thus may worsen angina.

Highyeild:

Dipyridamole It is a powerful coronary dilator; it increases total coronary flow by preventing uptake and degradation of adenosine which is a local mediator involved in autoregulation of coronary flow in response to ischaemia. It dilates resistance vessels and abolishes autoregulation but does not affect larger conducting coronary vessels. Cardiac work is not decreased because the venous return is not reduced. Accordingly, it fails to relieve anginal symptoms or avert ECG changes. The pharmacological success but therapeutic failure of dipyridamole has been explained based on the ‘coronary steal’ phenomenon. By dilating resistance vessels in the non-ischaemic zone, it also diverts the already reduced blood flow away from the ischaemic zone.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Diltiazem is used to treat angina (heart-related chest pain), high blood pressure, and some types of irregular heartbeats (arrhythmia). It is known as a calcium channel blocker and works by relaxing blood vessels to lower blood pressure. This helps to reduce the workload of the heart. Option: C. Propranolol is a medication of the beta blocker class. It is used to treat high blood pressure, several types of irregular heart rate, thyrotoxicosis, capillary hemangiomas, performance anxiety, and essential tremors, as well as to prevent migraine headaches. Option: D. Verapamil is used to treat angina (heart-related chest pain), high blood pressure, and some types of irregular heartbeats (arrhythmia). It works by relaxing blood vessels to lower blood pressure. This helps to reduce the workload of the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication of verapamil?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Variant angina

Highyeild:

Contraindications of Verapamil:- i. 2nd and 3rd degree AV block ii. WPW syndromeiii. SA node dysfunction iii. Lown-Ganong-Levine syndrome iv. Neuromuscular transmission deficiency. v. Wide-complex ventricular tachycardia Verapamil side effects, interactions, and contraindications: Constipation is the most common side effect. Bradycardia and nausea are more common than with dhps, while flushing, headache, and ankle edema are less common. Hypotension is occasional. It can accentuate conduction defects (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd-degree A-V block) and precipitate CHF in patients with preexisting disease. Cardiac arrest has occurred on i.v. Injection and when it is given to patients with sick sinuses.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. PSVT with AV block Option: C. Lown-Ganong-Levine syndrome Option: D. Beta-adrenergic block note:b, c, d verapamil are contraindicated.

questions.text: Among the following options, Nitroglycerin causes all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypotension and bradycardia

Highyeild:

SIDE EFFECTS OF NITROGLYCERINE bursting, pulsating headache decreasing of arterial pressure (tachycardia, dizziness, collapse - postural hypotension) facial flushing, feeling of fever a. Nitrates are the most commonly used antianginal drugs. b. These act by delivering nitric oxide into the blood vessels leading to vasodilation. c. Per Merry’s law, hypotension is followed by tachycardia and not bradycardia. d. Constipation and gastroesophageal reflux disease is a common problem in patients taking nitrates.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Methemoglobinemia is a condition of elevated methemoglobin in the blood. Symptoms may include headache, dizziness, shortness of breath, nausea, poor muscle coordination, and blue-colored skin (cyanosis). Option: C . Hypotension and tachycardia: Because the ventricles do not have enough time to fill up usually, the amount of blood effectively pumped out of the heart is reduced. Medication: Commonly used medication may cause the unwanted side effect of tachycardia and low blood pressure. Option: D. Vasodilation, also known as vasorelaxation , is the widening of blood vessels. It results from the relaxation of smooth muscle cells within the vessel walls, particularly in the large veins, large arteries, and smaller arterioles. The process is the opposite of vasoconstriction, which is the narrowing of blood vessels.
